STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
August 23, 2022
Mark Lambert
Good Will Farm Association Inc dba U.P. Kids
PO Box 428
Houghton, MI 49931
RE: License #: CB310282171
U.P. KIDS
P.O. Box 428
57 Huron Street
Houghton, MI 49931
Dear Mr. Lambert:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
August 18, 2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the MSA and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of
this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Kari Muntean, Area Manager, at 734-395-0920.
Sincerely,
Doug Turrill, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 11
701 S. Elmwood
Traverse City, MI 49684
(734) 395-0920
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB310282171
Licensee Name: Good Will Farm Association Inc dba U.P. Kids
Licensee Address: 57 Huron Street
Houghton, MI 49931
Licensee Telephone #: (906) 482-0520
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Mark Lambert, Administrator
Name of Facility: U.P. KIDS
Facility Address: P.O. Box 428
57 Huron Street
Houghton, MI 49931
Facility Telephone #: (906) 482-0520
Original Issuance Date: 03/21/2006
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION
1

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement.
(3) An agency shall document review of the foster
parent/agency agreement with the foster family at least
annually and, when needed, develop a new agreement.
Two of three foster home files reviewed did not contain updated parent/agency
agreements. One file documented that the reevaluation was completed on February
24, 2022, but there was no updated agreement for the reevaluation year. In a
second file the reevaluation was due December 2, 2021, and there was no updated
agreement for the reevaluation year.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by
another agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record
containing all of the following documents:
(a) Prior approval from the certifying agency authorizing
the placement of a child in the home.
One of three borrowed home files documented prior approval however it was dated
February 17, 2022. The placement occurred on February 15, 2022.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(b) Documentation that the foster parent is willing to accept
the foster child.
4

Three of three borrowed home files contained documentation that the foster parent
was willing to accept the child however the acceptance was late in each file. In one
file the placement of the child occurred on July 15, 2022, and the foster parent
signed a document accepting the child on August 3, 2022. A second file documented
that the child was placed on February 15, 2022, and the foster parent signed a
document accepting the child on February 17, 2022. A third file documented that the
child was placed on October 6, 2021, and the foster parent signed a document
accepting the child on November 8, 2021.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(c) A copy of the initial evaluation with written endorsement
by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is acceptable.
Three of three borrowed home files did not contain documentation of written
endorsement of initial evaluation.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(d) A copy of the current reevaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is
acceptable.
Three of three borrowed home files did not contain documentation of written
endorsement of reevaluations.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received
orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency.
5

Three of three borrowed home files documented that the foster parent received the
agency policies and procedures post placement. One file documented that the
placement occurred on February 15, 2022, and the foster parent received the
policies on February 15, 2022. A second file documented that the placement
occurred on July 15, 2022, and foster parent received the policies on August 3,
2022. A third file documented that the placement occurred on October 6, 2021, and
the foster parent received the policies November 8, 2021.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement signed by
the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
Three of three borrowed home files documented that the foster parent received the
parent/agency agreement post placement or the agreement was not signed. One file
documented that the placement occurred on February 15, 2022, and there were no
foster parent signatures indicating that they received the agreement. A second file
documented that the placement occurred on July 15, 2022, and the foster parent
signed the agreement on August 3, 2022. A third file documented that the placement
occurred October 6, 2021, and the foster parent did not sign the agreement until
November 8, 2021.
R 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to a
youth before placement in independent living.
One of one file reviewed did not contain documentation that the youth received the
independent living program statement prior to placement.
R 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living with a
copy of the agency's policies and procedures required by this
rule.
One of one file reviewed did not contain documentation that the youth received the
independent living program policy and procedures.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract between the
youth and the agency specifying all of the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
6

One of one file reviewed did not contain documentation that the youth received a
mutually agreed upon independent living contract.
R 400.12505 Supervision
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
(a) Face-to-face contact between the social service worker and
the youth in independent living at least once each month at a
youth’s place of residence.
One of one file reviewed did not contain documentation that a monthly in home
contact occurred during the month of July 2022.
R 40012418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows: (a) Within 30 calendar days
from removal from the home. (b) Within 120 calendar days after
the initial removal and at least once every 90 calendar days
thereafter.
One of three foster care files reviewed contained a service plan that was late. The
plan was due on April 6, 2022, and it was completed on July 21, 2022.
Repeat Violation: Interim Inspection September 9, 2021. CAP approved
September 25, 2021
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following. Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date. Updated Case
Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan
due date.
7

The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is used to
capture family demographics, FTM logistical information,
needs, strengths, action steps, safety concerns and the
safety plan, and any recommendations made for the family
during the FTM. The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be
completed for every FTM.
Three of three foster care files contained one or more FTM’s that were not
completed. In one file the last documented FTM occurred on June 3, 2021. Four
service plan periods had occurred without an FTM. In a second file there was no
documentation that FTM’s had occurred from November 11, 2021, to July 15, 2022.
In a third file there was no DHS-1105 completed for FTM’s that occurred on October
13, 2021, and June 21, 2022. This same file did not contain documentation that an
FTM occurred for a service plan period dated October 23, 2021, to January 18,
2022.
FOM 722-06H Case Contacts – Timely Entry
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face
contacts listed below in the electronic case management
record within five business days of the contact. This
includes attempted and missed face-to-face contacts. • Any
face-to-face contact with children, parents, or caregivers
made by any of the following: Foster care caseworker or
supervisor. Child protective services (CPS) caseworker or
supervisor. Adoption caseworker or supervisor.
Permanency resource monitors. Michigan Youth
Opportunities Initiative (MYOI) coordinators.
Three of three files contained face to face social work contacts that were entered
late. One file contained one contact that was entered late. A second file contained
five contacts that were entered late. A third file contained three contacts that were
entered late.
FOM 722-16 DHS-1295, Young Adult Monthly Visit Report
The DHS-1295, Young Adult Monthly Visit Report, must be
completed with the youth during each home visit. A copy
must be uploaded into M\ISACWIS a copy must be given to
the youth.
8

One of one YAVC files reviewed did not contain the DHS-1295 for the months of
April, May, and June 2022.
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans - signatures
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable.
• Caseworker. • Supervisor. • Parents who are a member of
a participating household. • Youth ages 14 and older. •
Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court
ordered caregivers.
Two of three foster care cases reviewed each contained PATP’s that lacked
signatures. In one file a PATP dated April 24, 2022, lacked signatures. A second
PATP dated January 24, 2022, lacked signatures. A second file contained a PATP
dated June 22, 2022, that lacked signatures.
FOM 801-03 Medical Passports
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.
Two of three foster care files reviewed documented that medical passports were not
updated quarterly. One file documented that the foster child was placed on August
31, 2021, and a medical passport was not completed until May 2, 2022. A second
file documented that the faster child was placed on October 6, 2021, and a medical
passport was not completed until August 12, 2022.
FOM 722-15 Case Closing DHS-69 Action Summary
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary,
must be completed at the time of program closure; see
FOM 722-08E, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary.
Two of two closed foster care files documented that the DHS-69 Action Summary
was completed late. One file documented that the case was closed on November
11, 2021, and the action summary was completed on December 9, 2021. A second
file documented that the case was closed on January 24, 2022, and the action
summary was completed on February 17, 2022.
ADM 330 QUARTERLY ADOPTION PROGRESS REPORTS
Adoption workers must submit written quarterly progress
reports using the DHS-614, Quarterly Adoption Progress
Report.
9

One of three adoption files reviewed contained Quarterly Adoption Progress Reports
that were completed late. The quarters were dated as follows, August 2, 2021, to
October 31,2021, November 1, 2021, to January 31, 2022, January 31, 2022, to May
1, 2022. Each of the reports for the respective quarters were completed on August 3,
2022.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
Technical assistance was provided regarding youth with YAFC status who are
placed in an independent living placement. Discussion involved YAFC youth, when
in an independent living arrangement such as a college dorm or an apartment, then
that youth is considered to be in independent living and the independent living rules
apply. The independent living rules do not apply to YAFC youth living with a relative,
in a foster home or a CCI.
V. CONSULTATION
Consultation was not requested or offered at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during
this licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted a corrective action plan on September 25, 2021 in response
to violations established during the interim inspection completed on September 9,
2021. During the current renewal inspection one repeat violation was established
regarding R 400.12418, late reports. The corrective action plan was otherwise
successful in preventing additional repeat violations. Also, during the licensing year,
the agency did not have any complaints filed against it and therefore there were no
special investigations initiated.
Chief Administrators Annual Assessment: (CAA)
The CAA was reviewed and it was thorough in addressing violations and CAP
successes during the licensing period. The CAA clearly identified areas of needed
improvement as well as areas of success.
10

Interviews:
The new Chief Administrator was interviewed and reported that staff turnover
presented challenges during the past year. She also reported that staff working from
home can present challenges but that she feels positive about the current foster care
and adoption team.
The licensing and adoption supervisor reported that the agency administration is
very supportive. She also reported that working from home can be difficult for some
staff.
Field Analyst Findings:
During the Field Analysts visit to the agency, four Safety Alerts were generated
regarding safety concerns noted in four homes.
Safety Alert #1. On July 22, 2022, a Safety Alert was generated and the agency
was notified. Twins had been sleeping in the same crib. The agency assured that a
second crib was added and provided photos of the second crib. The foster parents
reported that each child now has their own crib for sleeping. The concern was
rectified on July 27, 2022.
Safety Alert #2. On July 20, 2022, a Safety Alert was generated regarding a
children’s bedroom door which had locks on the outside. The Agency was notified on
July 20, 2022 and new door knobs without locks were installed and the concern was
rectified on July 26, 2022.
Safety Alert #3. On July 20, 2022, a Safety Alert was generated regarding reported
spanking of the foster children and an adult sleeping in a bedroom which contained
a clothes washer and dryer. The agency initiated a special investigation which did
not establish that the foster parent was spanking children. A variance was completed
regarding the adult sleeping in a room with a washer and dryer.
Safety Alert #4. On July 14, 2022, a Safety Alert was generated regarding the home
lacking a carbon monoxide detector. The agency was notified on July 14, 2022. On
July 27, 2022, the agency verified that a Carbon monoxide detector was installed in
the home.
During the entrance conference the Field Analyst provided the agency with
information she had obtained during her visits to the homes. The Field Analyst
reported that foster parents and relatives feel supported by the agency and no
concerns were raised.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
11

an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
August 23, 2022
________________________________________
Doug Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
August 23, 2022
________________________________________
Kari Muntean Date
Area Manager
